MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Absenteeism in Industry.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce the plans, or proposals, if any, he has to reduce absenteeism in Irish industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Reynolds)
Speaker.P: Absenteeism in industry is essentially a management problem and can best be tackled at the level of the individual firm. It is not a matter in which I, as Minister, can have a direct function. The Irish Productivity Centre, in 1986, initiated an absenteeism control programme to promote measures to reduce absenteeism including the installation by employers of standard measurement and control procedures and the creation of a general awareness in both management and workers alike of the social and economic effects of absenteeism.

MainHeading.P: In addition, in order to impress on firms the importance of absenteeism controls, State agencies such as the IDA and SFADCo., require firms seeking grant assistance to provide information on absenteeism levels and control procedures and these factors are taken into account when requests for grants are being considered. In the light of these activities, I see no need at this stage for further initiatives on my part.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce the number of petrol stations in the Dublin area which are owned and operated by persons or companies other than petrol distribution companies, i.e., the number of independent petrol stations; his views on whether any restrictive practice may be involved in this area or any possibility of an abuse of a monopoly position; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Reynolds)
Speaker.P: Statistics are not available on a geographic basis in relation to the ownership and operation of petrol stations; such statistics are only returned nationally.

Under successive Restrictive Practices Orders since 1972 the number of petrol stations owned or operated by petrol distribution companies has been frozen at the number in existence at that time and, under the terms of the existing Order — Restrictive Practices (Motor Spirit and Motor Lubricating Oil) Order, 1981 — new wholesalers or suppliers to the market may not own or operate more than 20 stations.

Those provisions and others in the order are designed to guard against unfair practices and the danger of any abuse of a monopoly position by any one or more of the major oil companies and I believe that they do so satisfactorily.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the amount of moneys being allocated from the national lottery to the various sporting organisations in Cork city and county; if she will disburse these funds in the same way as announced by the previous Government; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The Government have decided that an allocation of £3,150,000 should be made from the proceeds of the national lottery to youth and sports projects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether the Government accept the report of the National Youth Policy Committee as the basis for their youth policy; and if so her priorities for action based upon this report.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The Government have decided to re-examine the whole area of youth policy. In conducting this re-examination all previous reports in this area including the report of the National Youth Policy Committee, will be taken into consideration.

asked the Minister for Education if she will extend the proceds from the national lottery to allow grants to be paid for recreational facilities and community centres; if she will accept applications for this; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The funds recently allocated to my Department by way of proceeds from the national lottery will be supplied to the area of grant-in-aid to youth and sport activities.

My Department have no plans, at this stage, for providing capital grant assistance towards recreational facilities and community centres in the context of the distribution of moneys received from the national lottery. Accordingly, the invitation of applications on this basis does not arise at the present time.
This matter will receive appropriate consideration by my Department in the context of any further funds which may be available from the national lottery in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the northside reading group is now faced with closure due to lack of funds, which threatens to cut off completely the scheme manned by voluntary tutors and which provides service to people whose education needs must be a very high ranking priority; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: From inquiries made by my Department I understand that the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee recently circularised principals of its post-primary schools advising them of their budgets. Principals were also asked for their views as to how their schools' programme for 1987 would be run so that the committee might ensure that its authorised financial allocation for 1987 is not exceeded. In replying to the committee I understand that the principal of the vocational school, used by the voluntary literacy group in question for night classes, referred to the possibility of having to close the school for some nights from September next in order to maintain essential services within his approved financial allocation. His views and the views of other principals are at present under consideration by the committee but the committee have taken no decision on the matter at issue here. I also understand that the committee do not intend to reduce the amount of the grant-in-aid made annually to this group for its activities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - St. John the Baptist (Dublin) School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a statement in relation to the proposed building project at St. John the Baptist junior and senior national school, Clontarf, Dublin 3; and when building is expected to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: St. John the Baptist junior and senior national schools, Clontarf, Dublin 3, have 26 class groups accommodated in 17 permanent classrooms and nine prefabricated classrooms. A revised outline sketch scheme for the provision of an extension to, and the improvement of, the permanent accommodation is currently under consideration in my Department. It will not be possible to advance this project significantly in the immediate future because of my Department's capital commitments in respect of contracts recently authorised, and the large number of other projects for which tenders have been received or which are at an advanced stage of planning. My Department's primary buildings branch will keep in touch with the school authorities regarding the further processing of their proposals.
